(Slide 10) Schools are under inspection: New Rules

New York: If colleges waste more than an average of 2 tons of food per week, they must donate leftovers and compost the waste.

Massachusetts: If colleges waste more than an average of 500 lbs of food per week, they must donate leftovers and compost the waste.

Oregon: Schools should set up a “food share program” so that leftover food can be picked up by students, and the rest sent to homeless shelters and food banks.

(Slide 12) Estimating Food Waste

Instead of having every school weigh their waste, researchers for New York have created a formula to approximate the waste for non-residential colleges and universities.

Non-Residential School Formula:

  • Food waste (lbs/year) = 0.35 lbs/meal * N of students * 108 meals/student/year

(Slide 15) Choice of 0.35 lbs/meal

Several studies* have reported information on food waste from college and university dining facilities.

The studies had a range from 0.27 lbs/meal to 0.73 lbs/meal, with a mean value of 0.39 lbs/meal, and a median value of 0.34 lbs/meal.

We chose to use 0.35 lbs/meal, between the mean and median values, to estimate food waste generation for this study.

We also found studies to be more accurate than self-reports from colleges.

* Including the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (1998d), Kim et al. (1997), Shanklin et al. (1997), Smith et al. (1998), the California Integrated Waste Management Board (2001), and Clark & Law (2000)

(Slide 16) Choice of 108 meals/student/year

From looking at the calendars of several colleges, we have assumed that the food is served on 270 days during the year.

Five non-residential colleges provided data:

  • Range: 0.17-0.96 meals/student/day
  • Median: 0.29 meals/student/day
  • Mean: 0.4 meals/student/day

Assuming the same value for food service activity on 270 days out of the year, and the mean value, we get an estimate of 108 meals served per enrolled student per year.
